metadata.title: Multiple Diffusivities Define White Matter Degeneration in Amnestic Mild Cognitive Impairment and Alzheimers Disease
metadata.abstract: Different diffusivity measurements in diffusion-tensor imaging (DTI) could be helpful for detecting the distinct mechanisms of white matter degeneration in Alzheimers disease (AD). However, few studies have explored the changes of white matter in amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) and AD by whole-brain voxel-wise analyses of all diffusivity indices. The association between grey matter atrophy and white matter damage measured by distinct diffusivities is still uncertain. Structural magnetic resonance imaging and DTI with four diffusivity indices, comprising fractional anisotropy, mean diffusivity, axial diffusivity, and radial diffusivity, were performed in 30 normal controls, 26 mild AD patients, and 40 aMCI patients with isolated memory impairment. T1 voxel-based morphometry and DTI tract-based spatial statistics were applied to compare the grey and white matter changes in the 3 groups. In contrast to the lack of significant white matter change presenting in aMCI patients, extended white matter degeneration over entire cerebral networks was exhibited in mild AD patients. Both axonal degradation and demyelination contributed to the white matter degeneration in AD; nevertheless, demyelination essentially involved the frontal portion of cerebral networks. Axonal degradation and demyelination over the temporal region were associated with the contiguous grey matter atrophy. However, only the severity of demyelination over the frontal region was correlated with the degree of atrophy over adjacent frontal grey matter. Our results suggest that different mechanisms of white matter damage demonstrate discrete regional distribution in AD. Demyelination may independently correlate with contiguous grey matter over the frontal region.

INTRODUCTION.text:
Increasing evidence supports amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI) as a very early or prodromal stage of Alzheimers disease (AD). By investigating the clinical and neuroimaging characteristics of normal aging, aMCI, and AD, we can obtain important information on pathogenesis and the evolution of AD.
Grey matter (GM) voxel-based morphometry (VBM) studies indicate that left medial temporal atrophy is the most consistent biomarker for predicting the progression from aMCI to AD 1. However, functional imaging revealed that the posterior cingulum is the most prominent hypometabolic region in the early stages of AD 2,3. Furthermore, a recent default mode network functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study demonstrated that disconnection over the posterior cingulate area precedes atrophy in this area 4. Therefore, damage of white matter (WM) fiber integrity may develop independently in the pathogenesis of AD.
The underlying mechanisms related to WM degeneration in AD remain uncertain. Changes in WM can be a primary event or secondary to the atrophy of GM. Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) is a noninvasive technique that can measure direction-dependent diffusivity of water molecules to reflect the underlying neural structure on a microscopic scale 5. DTI has been used to detect the integrity of WM fibers, which is undetectable by conventional MRI 6,7. Most previous DTI studies adapted its derived indices, fractional anisotrophy (FA) or mean diffusivity (MD), to indicate the severity of WM damage in AD or aMCI, where FA is the relative ratio of axial to radial diffusivities and is usually used to indicate the integrity of WM fibers, while MD means the average diffusivity of all three dimensions 6,7. A recent DTI meta-analysis study demonstrated that regions with altered MD and FA happened in most of the brain regions in AD and aMCI subjects 5. In addition to the between-studies variation of recruited subjects, this high heterogeneity might arise from the different diffusivity measures and methods of analysis used. Furthermore, FA only indirectly probes the microstructural properties of WM 8. Decrease in FA has been found in various pathologies 9101112 and regions where there are crossing fibers 8.
MD represents the average diffusivity of all three dimensions. FA is the relative ratio of axial to radial diffusivities and is indicative of the integrity of WM fibers 9,10. However, FA only indirectly probes the microstructural properties of WM 11. Decrease in FA has been found in various pathologies 12131415, and crossing fibers also produces variations in FA.
Recently, the separation of the diffusivities into axial (DA) and radial (DR) components has been validated as a specific measure in the longitudinal and transverse diffusion directions 16. Change in DA indicates axonal damage in fibers; in contrast, alteration in DR supports demyelination with disruption of myelin integrity 17. By measuring the changes of DA and DR, Di Paola and colleagues reported both axonal degeneration and myelin breakdown might be responsible for the callosal degeneration in AD patients 18. Few neuroimaging studies have explored the WM changes in AD patients using whole-brain voxel-wise analyses of four different diffusion indices 19202122, and only two of them enrolled aMCI patients 21,22. Knowledge of the characteristics of WM degeneration in the aMCI and AD remains scant.
We recruited aMCI patients with isolated memory impairment to avoid subjects who may already have been early AD. Whole-brain VBM and tract-based spatial statistics (TBSS) analyses were applied to examine changes in GM and WM. We hypothesized that both GM atrophy with secondary axonal degeneration and retrogenesis with demyelination would be found in the WM pathology of AD. We aimed to explore the characteristic distribution of and the correlations between GM and WM degeneration in aMCI and AD patients.

Participants.text: A total of 96 human subjects, including 40 aMCI patients, 26 AD patients, and 30 normal control (NC) elders, were recruited. This study was approved by the Local Ethics Committee of Human Research in Taipei Veterans General Hospital, Taiwan. All subjects and guardians of the AD patients provided written informed consent prior to participation in this study. They had no history of brain trauma, brain tumor, stroke, epilepsy, alcoholism, major psychiatric illness, or other systemic diseases that could affect brain function. An experienced radiologist (Dr. Lirng) reviewed the severity of WM signal hyperintensities (WMSH) on MRI. To minimize the effect of severe WM change in image processing, only subjects with mild WMSH 23 were recruited for this study.

Clinical assessments.text:
All participants received standard clinical, neurological, and neuropsychological assessments. Our neurosychological battery included the Mini-Mental-State Examination (MMSE) 24, the Chinese version Verbal Learning Test (CVVLT; 9 items, 4 trials, and10min delayed recall) 25, the modified Rey-Osterrieth complex figure test (CFT) 26, the categorical verbal fluency test (animals), the 30-item Boston Naming Test 27, and the modified Trail-Making Test, Part B 28. Dementia severity was assessed by the clinical dementia rating (CDR) scale 29. Depression symptoms were examined by the Chinese version Geriatric Depression Scale-short form (GDS-S) 30. Vascular risk factors, including presence of diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease, were recorded.
AD was diagnosed according to the criteria of the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke-Alzheimers Disease and Related Disorders Association 31. AD patients enrolled in this study were mild AD with a CDR score of 1. Our aMCI patients fulfilled Petersens criteria 32: 1) memory complaints; 2) objective memory impairment (CVVLT 6) 25; 3) normal general cognitive function (MMSE 24); 4) intact daily living activities; and 5) dementia criteria not met. Only aMCI patients with isolated memory impairment and without evidence of any additional cognitive dysfunction were recruited for this study.
A blood sample was drawn from all the participants. The apolipoprotein E (ApoE) genotype was determined using PCR and the restriction enzyme digestion method 13.

Clinical data analysis.text: Statistical analysis was performed using the Statistical Package for Social Sciences (SPSS) software package, version 16 for Windows. Baseline demographic data were compared using analysis of variance (ANOVA) with a post hoc Tukey test. Scores of neuropsychological tests were compared by analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) with age, gender, education as covariates and using post-hoc Tukey adjustment for multiple comparisons Categorical data were compared by χ 2 tests.

Image acquisition.text: All patients received an MRI scan within 1 month after their cognitive assessment. Images were acquired on a 1.5-T GE MR system (Excite II; Milwaukee, WI) with an eight-channel head coil. To minimize motion artifact generated during the scan, the subjects head was immobilized with cushions inside the coil. High resolution structural data were acquired using an axial T1-weighted three-dimensional fluid-attenuated inversion-recovery fast spoiled gradient recalled echo (3D FLAIR-FSPGR) sequence (TRTETI  8.5481.836 ms400 ms, flip angle  15  , FOV  26 cm, 124 slices, matrix size  256  256 and slice thickness  1.5 mm). Whole brain diffusionweighted data were acquired using a single-shot echoplanar imaging sequence (TRTE  1700068.9 ms, NEX  6, matrix size  128  128, FOV  26 cm, voxel size  2.03  2.03  2 mm 3 , 70 axial slices, b value  900 smm 2 , 13 diffusion directions and 1 scan without diffusion weighting (b value  0 smm 2 ).

White matter microstructure analysis (DT.text:
All DTI datasets were preprocessed using FSL v4.1.6 (Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging of the Brain Software Library; http:www. fmrib.ox.ac.ukfsl). To reduce the motion effect and to minimize the eddy current distortion caused by fast-switching gradient, the diffusion weighted images of each individual were linearly registered to the non-diffusion weighted image by using the command-line tool eddy correct, which is available in FMRIBs Diffusion Toolbox (FDT; part of FSL). Subsequently, the DTI datasets were skull stripped using the Brain Extraction Tool (BET; part of FSL) 33 to remove the background noise and non-tissue components.
After preprocessing, FA, MD, DA (axial diffusion component), and DR (transverse diffusion component) of each voxel were calculated based on Bassers DTI model 10 using an in-house software. Voxel-wise analysis of the DTI-related indices was carried out using TBSS 34, which was implemented in FSL. Briefly, to increase the registration accuracy across the subjects, one FA map was determined to be the most representative FA map which caused the minimal warping when all the other FA maps were registered to it. To find the most representative FA maps of the entire study group, we registered every subject to each other using the command-line tool tbss 2 reg with the -n flag, which is available in FSL. This function summarizes the mean displacement of each FA image and then chooses the most representative FA map as being the one with the minimum mean displacement distance to all other subjects. This most representative FA map was then affinetransformed to the Oxford FMRIB58 FA standard template using FMRIBs Linear Image Registration Tool (FLIRT; part of FSL). All participants FA maps were transformed into MNI standard space by combining the non-linear image transfer to the most representative FA map using FMRIBs Non-linear Image Registration Tool (FNIRT, part of FSL) with the affine transform from the most representative FA map to MNI standard space. The final normalized FA images were resampled into 1 mm cubic resolution. All normalized FA maps were averaged to create a crosssubject mean FA image, which was skeletonized to construct a mean WM skeleton. The FA threshold of the mean WM skeleton was set at 0.2 to exclude voxels consisting of GM or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the majority of subjects. Each subjects transformed FA data were projected onto this mean WM skeleton by filling the skeleton with FA values from the nearest relevant tract center. To simultaneously investigate MD, DA, and DR, the transformation matrix and skeleton projection information of FA obtained in the above steps were applied to the other diffusivity maps.
To identify differences among the three groups, voxel-wise permutation-based nonparametric ANCOVA design was used 35. Age, gender, and years of formal education were included as covariates of no interest in the model. Statistical inference on each contrast was performed using 5000 permutations at random (Randomise, part of FSL).
Group-related differences were investigated using the Threshold Free Cluster Enhancement (TFCE approach), a clustering algorithm without an arbitrary threshold for the initial cluster formation 24. To avoid the multiple comparison problems, the cluster maps were assessed for significance using FWE-corrected statistics for an appropriate correction (FWE-corrected p  0.05).
The most possible fiber tracts and anatomic localization of each significant cluster were determined using the JHU White Matter Tractrography atlas of the FSL atlas tool (http:www.fmrib.ox. ac.ukfslfslviewatlas.html).

Grey matter macrostructure analysis (T1.text:
T1 VBM with the DARTEL registration scheme was used for preprocessing and the analysis of the wholebrain T1-weighted volumetric images 36,37. Individual T1-weighted volumetric images were analyzed with Gasers toolbox VBM5 (http:dbm.neuro.unijena.devbm) on SPM5 (Statistical Parametric Mapping, Wellcome Department of Imaging Neuroscience, London, UK; http:www.fil.ion.ucl.ac.ukspm) implemented in Matlab 7.3 (MathWorks, Natick, MA, USA). Whole-brain native space T1-weighted images were bias-field corrected and tissue-classified into GM, WM, and CSF partitions based on the generative model unified segmentation 38. This segmentation procedure was further refined by applying an iterative hidden Markov field (HMRF) model 39 to minimize the influence of the noise level during segmentation.
To achieve higher accuracy of registration across subjects, the segmented native space GM, WM, and CSF tissue segments were imported into a rigidly aligned space and iteratively registered to studyspecific customized tissue templates, which were generated from all images in the whole study group through non-linear warping using the DARTEL toolbox in SPM5 (Diffeomorphic Anatomical Registration Through Exponentiated Lie Algebra) 29. The spatially registered tissue segments were then multiplied by the Jacobian determinants derived from the nonlinear deformation. The final voxel size after the entire procedure was 1 mm cubic. All normalized, segmented, and modulated MNI standard space images were smoothed with an 8-mm Gaussian kernel in advance of the tissue volume calculation and voxelwise group comparisons. The overall tissue volumes were estimated in 1 mm 3 by counting the voxels representing GM, WM, and CSF in standard space. The total intracranial volume (TIV) was determined from the sum of the GM, WM, and CSF volumes.
To ensure that statistical thresholds in T1 VBM and DTI TBSS analysis were comparable, the smoothed modulated GM segments were analyzed using FSL 4.1.6 with a framework of permutation-based nonparametric testing (Randomise, part of FSL tool; http:www.fmrib.ox.ac.ukfslrandomiseindex.html) 40. ANCOVA was used with the covariates of TIV, age, gender, and years of formal education to investigate the differences in regional GM volume among the 3 groups. The TFCE clustering approach used in the DTI-TBSS analysis was used again to determine significant clusters, and FWE corrected p  0.05 was used to correct for multiple comparisons across space. Only clusters sized larger than 50 voxels were reported. Anatomical structures of the coordinates representing significant clusters were identified on the basis of the Talairach and Tournoux atlas 41.

The effect of ApoE genotype and vascular.text: The mean values of four DTI indices (MD, DA, DR, and FA) and GM volumes in the clusters showed differences in the main effects of 3 group comparisons were extracted. To exam the effect of ApoE on GM and WM in the 3 diagnostic groups, subjects were further subgrouped according to their ApoE genotypes. Because only 2 subjects had 24 and all 3 subjects with 44 were AD patients, we focused on the comparisons among 23 (2 carriers), 33 (3 homozygosity), and 34 (4 carriers) subgroups. There were no significant differences in GM volumes and DTI values among ApoE genotypes in all of 3 diagnostic groups. (supplementary Table 3). The vascular risk factors, including diabetes, hypertension, cardiovascular disease, did not show effects on all of the GM and WM measures.

Anatomical correspondence and quantitati.text: To check the relationship between GM atrophy and WM abnormality in the anatomical correspondence regions, we overlaid the results of T1 VBM and DTI TBSS analyses in the comparison of AD and NC on the same anatomical image. We visually identified areas of anatomical correspondence between higher MD regions and adjacent regions of GM atrophy which method was also used in previous bimodal imaging studies 42,43. Each of the clusters demonstrating obvious anatomical overlaid between GM atrophy and MD increase were identified. The mean values of four DTI indices (FA, MD, DA, and DR) and GM volumes of these clusters were retracted. ANCOVA with a post hoc Tukey analysis was applied to examine the DTI values and GM differences among the 3 study groups. The correlations between the diffusivity indices and GM volumes of these areas in aMCI and AD patients were examined using the Spearmans rank correlation coefficient. The correlations between these imaging measures and neuropsychological tests scores were checkeds.

Demographics.text:
Table 1 lists the demographics and clinical information of the participants. The mean age and gender distribution did not differ across the 3 study groups. The AD patients had fewer years of education than the subjects in the other 2 groups, the difference was not statistically significant (F  3.040, p  0.054). No group difference in GDS-S among the 3 groups was found. Cholinesterase inhibitors were used in 21 (80.7) of our AD patients, and eight of them received concurrent memantine treatment.
Regarding the distribution of ApoE genotypes, 9 subjects had 23, 2 subjects had 24, 53 subjects had 33, 29 subjects had 34, and 3 subjects had 44. The frequency of the ApoE 4 carrier was highest in the AD group (56.5), followed by the MCI (35.5), and then the NC group (17.9) (Table 1). All of the 3 subjects with 44 genotype were patients of AD.
No group differences were noted in the presence of diabetes, hypertension and cardiovascular disease.

Performance of neuropsychological tests.text: The AD group demonstrated significantly poorer performance in all of the neuropsychological tests than the NC group. The cognitive performance of the aMCI patients was intermediate between that of the NC and AD patients. However, only the difference in scores of the memory tests (delayed recall in CVVLT and CFT) were significant between aMCI and NC.

Comparisons of DTI diffusivities by TBSS.text: Extended WM differences were noted in the main effects of 3 group comparisons (supplementary Figure 1; available online: http:www.j-alz.comissues 30vol30-2.htmlsupplementarydata04). To examine which group contributed to these differences, we focused on reporting the results of the post hoc between group comparison. The detailed anatomical locations and MNI coordinates of WM clusters differed in the 2-group comparisons are presented in supplementary Table 1.

Decrease of FA.text:
Compared with NC subjects, AD patients revealed FA decrease over the bilateral parahippocampal WM, forceps minor, superior longitudinal fasciculus (SLF), inferior longitudinal fasciculus (ILF), inferior frontooccipital fasciculus (IFO), superior fronto-occipital fasciculus (SFO), uncinate fasciculus (UF), anterior cingulum, and right anterior thalamic radiation (Fig. 1a). The frontal portions of these fibers were extendedly involved.
Compared with the aMCI patients, AD patients exhibited FA decrease over all of the above fibers as well as the genu and anterior midbody of the corpus callosum (CC) (Fig. 1b).

Increase of MD.text: MD revealed the most extended between-group differences in all of the four diffusivity indices (FA, MD, DR, and DA). Compared with NC subjects, AD patients exhibited increased MD in the bilateral parahippocampal WM, cingulum, entire CC, SLF, ILF, SFO, IFO, and UF (Fig. 1c). Compared with aMCI patients, AD patients presented increase of MD in all of the above areas except the splenium of CC, posterior cingulum, parietal portions of the SLF, and ILF (Fig. 1d).

Increase of DR.text:
Compared with NC subjects, most of the fibers that presented MD increase also presented DR increase in AD patients, except those over the splenium of CC (Fig. 1e). The frontal portions of these cortico-cortical fibers were more likely to be involved than the parietal portions.
Compared with aMCI patients, AD patients exhibited DR increase in similar regions in the comparison of AD and NC (Fig. 1f).

Increase of DA.text:
Compared with NC subjects, most of the fibers that presented MD increase also demonstrated DA increase in AD patients, but the areas were less extended (Fig. 1g).
AD patients did not differ from aMCI patients in DA over any cerebral region (Fig. 1h).

Contribution of DR and DA to the changes.text: We applied TBSS analysis to examine the changes of DA and DR in the regions presenting MD increase in the comparison between NC subjects and AD patients. Most of the regions that presented MD increase demonstrated increase of both DR and DA; however, DR did not increase over the splenium of the CC (Fig. 2). DR increase was shown mostly over the anterior portion of the CC and the frontal portion of cerebral fasciculi.

Comparisons of DTI indices between the N.text: No FA, MD, DA, or DR differences were found between NC and aMCI participants.

Comparisons of the GM by T1 DARTEL VBM.text: Differences in the GM over bilateral temporal and frontal regions were noted in the main effects of the 3 group comparisons (supplementary Figure 1). Compared with NC subjects, aMCI patients exhibited GM atrophy only in the left medial temporal lobe. However, AD patients had more extended GM atrophy than aMCI and NC over the bilateral temporal as well as the medial frontal and superior frontal gyri (Fig. 3). The detailed MNI coordinates and anatomical locations of these GM clusters are listed in supplementary Table 2.

Anatomical correspondence between GM atr.text:
The MD increase map in AD was overlapped with the GM atrophy map to check the anatomical correspondence between GM and WM degeneration (Fig. 4). Two clusters demonstrated obvious GM and WM connection. One was over the left temporal region, and the other was over the left frontal area.
Correlations between GM volume and the diffusivity indices in the corresponding GM and WM clusters were examined in aMCI and AD patients (Table 2). Spearmans correlation tests revealed that the degrees of change in the four diffusivity indices in the left temporal region were all correlated with the severity of the atrophy in adjacent temporal regions (r  0.58-0.69 for four diffusivity indices) and left frontal region (r  0.33-0.42 for four diffusivities). The degrees of GM atrophy of the frontal region (r  -0.16, p  0.594) nor correlated with the left temporal region (r  -0.23, p  0.437).

Correlations between neuropsychological.text: The Spearmans rank correlation coefficient between scores of neuropsychological tests, GM volumes, and diffusivity values are shown in Table 3. Larger GM volumes, higher FA, and lower MD, DA, and DR of the left hippocampal and fontal regions were correlated with scores of the MMSE, 10-min recall in CVVLT, 10-min recall in CFT, and Trail-making Test Part B in aMCI and AD patients (r  0.25-0.64). The scores of these tests were more strongly correlated with the measures over the left temporal region than the left frontal region.

DISCUSSION.text:
The advantage of this study is that we concurrently examined the changes of GM and four different DTI indices in normal aging, aMCI, and mild AD patients. This approach allowed us to investigate the characteristic anatomical distribution of different types WM damage in aMCI and AD patients.
Because aMCI subjects with multiple cognitive domains impairment may already have pathological changes close to those in mild AD 44, we enrolled aMCI patients with isolated memory impairment to investigate how WM degeneration develops in the aMCI stage. By checking the changes in GM and WM at the same statistical threshold, we found that left medial temporal atrophy is distinct in aMCI; in contrast, WM degeneration is not evident at this stage.
The diffusivities measured in DTI can be decomposed into three mutually orthogonal eigenvectors and the corresponding eigenvalues: λ1, λ2, and λ3. The MD stands for the average diffusivity from three overall dimensions ((λ1  λ2  λ3)3) 5. The relative ratio of axial to radial diffusivities is known as FA 9,10. Most previous DTI studies focused on using the change in FA or MD to identify the severity of the WM damage in AD or aMCI. However, decrease of FA has been found in variable pathologies, including disruption of myelin integrity, changes in axonal morphologic structure, alteration of inter-axonal spacing of fiber bundles, CSF, and local edema 12131415. Furthermore, crossing fibers also produces variation in FA 14.
Recently, separating the diffusivity measurement into axial and radial components has been validated to indicate changes in nerve fibers more specifically 16,454647. The axial component, DA, is the diffusion coefficient along the direction of maximal apparent diffusion (λ1), and the radial component, DR, is the average of the second and third eigenvalues ((λ2  λ3)2). Alteration of DA is an indicator of axonal damage and wallerian degeneration 17,48. In contrast, change in radial diffusivity (DR) signifies the disruption of myelin integrity in the demyelinating process 16,45.
Two other studies 21,22 evaluate the WM changes in aMCI and AD patients by whole-brain voxel-wise analysis with four diffusivity indices. Bosch et al. reported that aMCI patients showed significant changes in several diffusivity indices 22. Douaud et al. found that only crossing fibers in the centrum semiovale showed significant anisotrophy changes in aMCI 21. However, we did not find any significant diffusivity differences between the NC and aMCI groups. In contrast to the isolated memory impairment in our aMCI patients, most of the aMCI patients in Douauds study are multi-domain aMCI. Conversely, better MMSE scores are noted in our aMCI than in Boschs aMCI patients (26.8 vs. 25.5). Therefore, our aMCI patients are in an earlier stage of aMCI than theirs. The WM damage may not have occurred or may be trivial in this early MCI stage.
FA is generally assumed to be a satisfactory marker of the integrity of WM tracts 14. This is based on the assumption that FA reductions are driven by increased DR and that constant DA occurs in demyelination and axonal loss. We noted that MD is more sensitive than FA in detecting WM changes in AD patients. Similar results are reported by other studies 20. In this study, most of the areas that showed decrease in FA also showed increase of both DR and DA. When the increase in DA is proportional to the increase in DR, FA would remain relatively unchanged 20,22. Therefore, investigating all possible measurements of DTI is extremely important in the research of neurodegenerative diseases.
In structural MRI studies, reduction of WM volumes are noted in AD patients 495051. Numerous pathology studies also support the idea that WM degeneration are involved in AD. Identified WM pathology in AD includes the decrease of myelin density 52, loss of oligodendrocytes 53, and activation of microglial cells 54. Comparable results were reported in DTI studies of AD patients. Measuring the different diffusivity indices of DTI demonstrates both axonal degeneration and myelin disruption in AD or MCI patients 20,22,55,56.
Examination of the nature of WM damage by different DTI measures in this study reveals that both axonal degradation and myelin disruption contribute to WM degeneration in AD. However, axonal damage (increase of DA) without obvious demyelination (no DR increase) is observed over the splenium of the CC. This suggests that Wallerian degeneration with axonal disintegration secondary to the GM atrophy over the temporal region is the principle WM pathology in the posterior portion of the CC. Demyelination is mainly located in the genu, anterior mid-body of the CC, and frontal portions of cortico-cortical fibers. Previous DTI studies of AD 575859 and Di Paolas study targeting the WM changes of CC in AD 60 reported similar findings. Our results support the theory that retrogenesis with demyelination in AD starts from the later-myelinating fibers located over the anterior part of the CC and cerebral networks 61,62.
In the correlation analysis, we confirmed that most of the measurements of WM damage in the temporal and frontal areas correlated with GM atrophy of the adjacent regions in aMCI and AD patients. Axonal damage in the temporal region was strongly correlated with atrophy over the temporal region. In contrast, the degree of myelin disruption, but not axonal damage, in the frontal region was correlated with the adjacent frontal atrophy. If WM change in the frontal region is followed by GM atrophy, then the degree of frontal atrophy should be strongly correlated with the degree of WM change in the adjacent frontal region. Our findings suggest that the retrogenesis process in the frontal region may contribute to GM atrophy over this region. A recent default-mode network fMRI study also demonstrated disconnection over the posterior cingulate area preceding the atrophy in this area 4. Our study is the first to suggest that the demyelinating process in the frontal region may contribute to the atrophy of the contiguous frontal GM. However, further prospective study is required to confirm whether the demyelinating process in the frontal region in AD patients contributes to the GM atrophy over this region.
We did not find differences in GM volumes and DTI values among ApoE genotypes in all of 3 diagnostic groups. Our previous study reported ApoE 4 carriers had smaller hippocampal volumes 63 and several studies also demonstrated the effect of ApoE 4 on GM and WM at medial temporal region in both normal aging 646566 and AD subjects 666768. Small sample size and unequal distribution of ApoE 4 genotype in 3 diagnostic groups may diminish the effect of 4 in this study. Recently, studies found persons with ApoE 33 and VLVL TOMM40 polymorphism had decreased GM volume in the posterior cingulate and precuneus areas 69. AD related risk factors, such as hyperhomocysteinemia, also may impair the function of ApoE 3 70. We did not check the serum homocysteine concentration and TOMM40 polymorphism of our subjects. Subgrouping ApoE 33 subjects based on their TOMM40 polymorphism or homocysteine level may provide more information regarding the effect of ApoE 3 on GM and WM.
Our study has some limitations. First, we only enrolled aMCI patients with isolated memory impairment. Using a less-affected sample may reduce the probability of finding WM changes in the early stage of AD. The other limitation is that this is a crosssectional study. Prospective investigation of GM and WM changes in a single individual would provide more direct information regarding the chronological changes in GM and WM in the evolution of AD.
Another issue concerns the intrinsic limitations of the techniques. The different registration techniques used in this study may introduce potential bias to our findings. Although the essence of registration algorithms in these two approaches is not the same, the registration approaches we applied in this study have been widely used to investigate GM and WM. Diffeomorphic based image registration is used in DARTEL T1 VBM, which is different from B-spline based registration in DTI TBSS. To reduce the potential bias due to the registration algorithm, the recent advanced diffeomorphic based DTI registration algorithms (i.e., full tensor information with non-parametric diffeomorphic deformable registration scheme) 71 and the diffeomorphic tensor-based registration approach 72 could be used.
In conclusion, both axonal degradation and demyelination over the temporal region were associated with contiguous GM atrophy. However, only the severity of demyelination over the frontal region was correlated with the degree of atrophy over the adjacent frontal GM. Further research prospectively investigating the sequential relationship between GM atrophy and different types of WM damage is required.
